title: How to Untie Shoelace or String Knots

steps.title: This may be all you need to untie tangled shoelaces or string.
steps.content: This may be all you need to untie tangled shoelaces or string. Instead of pulling on both ends right away to try and undo the knot, start by grabbing 1 end and pulling on it gently. If the knot is really just a tangled mess of intertwined loops and bows, rather than a tight knot, it should come undone right away. [1] X Research source If the knot doesn’t come undone this way, don’t yank on the end of the string you’re pulling on, or you can end up tightening the knot.

steps.title: Sometimes, pulling on a knot just makes it worse.
steps.content: Sometimes, pulling on a knot just makes it worse. Instead of pulling on the 2 sides of the knot to try to loosen it up, try to push 1 side back through the other to loosen it up a bit and give yourself some slack to work with. Squeeze, twist, and wiggle different parts of the knot until you’re able to loosen it up enough to untie. [2] X Research source If you don’t have any luck with your fingers, you can use a pair of needle-nosed pliers to try and push slack into the knot. Just be careful not to damage your shoelaces or the string by gripping too hard.

steps.title: Water can loosen the knot’s fibers.
steps.content: Water can loosen the knot’s fibers. Submerge the knot in water and let it soak for 10 minutes or so. Remove it and try to untie it again by pushing, pulling, and wiggling it from different angles. [3] X Research source

steps.title: It might be easier to loosen the knot with your teeth than with your fingers.
steps.content: It might be easier to loosen the knot with your teeth than with your fingers. Bite the knot between your teeth and give it a little chew. Try pulling on the top side of the knot with your teeth as well, twisting and wiggling it in different directions until it comes loose. [4] X Research source The saliva in your mouth also helps loosen the fibers of the knot.

steps.title: A fork is an easy-to-find utensil that can help wiggle knots loose.
steps.content: A fork is an easy-to-find utensil that can help wiggle knots loose. Slide the tooth of a fork into the center of the knot and pull up. Wiggle the fork and continue to pull until the 2 sides of the knot are loose enough for you to untie them. [5] X Research source If you don’t have a fork handy, you could use another skinny, pointy utensil, like a bamboo skewer, in a similar fashion.

steps.title: A corkscrew is another handy utensil for loosening knots.
steps.content: A corkscrew is another handy utensil for loosening knots. Poke the tip of a corkscrew under the top shoelace or string and twist it clockwise to work it into the knot. Once it’s fully under the string, pull up to loosen that side of the knot. Repeat the process for the bottom lace or string to fully loosen and undo the knot. [6] X Research source The corkscrew on a pocket knife works great for doing this.

steps.title: The sharp points on safety pins are ideal for undoing stubborn knots.
steps.content: The sharp points on safety pins are ideal for undoing stubborn knots. To do so, open up the safety pins and slide the points through the middle of each string on each side of the knot, where you would normally grab the strings between your fingers to untie it. Close the safety pins, then pull on them and wiggle them until the knot loosens and you can finish untying it with your fingers. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Adult fingers can sometimes be too big to undo tight knots.
steps.content: Adult fingers can sometimes be too big to undo tight knots. If you’re at your wits' end with a stubborn knot, get a friend or family member to give it a shot. A new perspective and a fresh set of fingers might just do the trick! [8] X Research source Someone with fingernails might have better luck than you, too, if your nails are freshly cut.

steps.title: Nylon has less friction than string or cloth.
steps.content: Nylon has less friction than string or cloth. Consider putting nylon shoelaces in your footwear if you frequently have problems untying knots in your laces. Or, use a nylon cord instead of a regular string for tying things up. [9] X Research source You can find nylon shoelaces online in a wide variety of colors, lengths, and thicknesses, so you shouldn’t have a problem finding laces that don’t alter the appearance of your shoes too much.
